comments:
Bugzilla didn't allow me to reopen 128604, but this bug happens to me with eclipse 3.2.1, M20060921-0945. 

The following error happens when I try to open Help Content in my RCP application:

The embedded application server could not run help web application

(The log is below the bugreport)

I have a plugin created by me: org.apache.commons.logging, with the following manifest:

Manifest-Version: 1.0
Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2
Bundle-Name: commons-logging Plug-in
Bundle-SymbolicName: org.apache.commons.logging;singleton:=true
Bundle-Version: 1.1.0
Bundle-ClassPath: commons-logging-1.1.jar
Bundle-Vendor: apache
Bundle-Localization: plugin
Export-Package: org.apache.commons.logging,
 org.apache.commons.logging.impl

which is used by another plugins by me. I also noticed tomcat plugin has its own commons-logging.jar inside. Is this case still a bug or there is some workaround possible?



----------------------------------------------------

Hmm I don't see how your classes are getting onto org.eclipse.tomcat's classpath, since it doesn't have a dependency to your bundle.

Some other projects like TPTP or WTP do the same thing, they use a newer version of commons-logging, packaged in a similar way, but for whatever reason they don't run into this problem.

For clues as to why this might happen, could you take a look at those projects' bundles and see how they bundle it differently? Another thing to check is whether you're doing anything special at all relating to classpaths or class loading.

Created an attachment (id=54792)
The simplest test case

Test case illustrating the problem. This is the simplest RCP application created by the wizard + help TOC also created by the wizard. The commons-logging plugin is packaged by me. The application invokes one logging operation on the startup ('run' method) which initializes commons-logging. Then - if you press help from the menu - you'll see the error. But if you comment out the logging line, and launch it again - help appears correctly.
You may need to click 'add required plugins' in the configuration b/c not everything is listed as direct dependency.

Curtis, thank you for response and insights. I cannot understand how it (the classloading problem) is possible either... but could you (anybody?) please kindly try the simplest testcase I attached and see if the problem is visible to you? Any thoughts? The testcase is really simple...

(In reply to comment #1)
> Some other projects like TPTP or WTP do the same thing, they use a newer
> version of commons-logging, packaged in a similar way, but for whatever reason
> they don't run into this problem.

BTW is there a newer version that 1.1? Do you mean they use repository head? Thank you for the suggestion, I'll check it...

Created an attachment (id=54795)
Classloading logs from running this application

Just in case - I'm attaching the logs after running the testcase with the logging commented out (log-ok.txt, longer) and with the logging present (log-bad.txt, shorter b/c it fails earlier ;)). Search for 'BundleClassLoader[org.eclipse.tomcat_4.1.130.v20060601].findClass(org.apache.log4j.Logger)' in both logs and you'll be close to the point it fails / not fails (depending on the log)

I have an interesting observation. I downloaded WTP and checked its commons-logging plugin. My testcase worked. Then I returned back to my commons-logging plugin and downgraded the commons-logging.jar from 1.1 I was using before to 1.0.4 that is used in WTP. *That worked*. 

My manifest differs from the WTP one, because I made it singleton plugin, not registered it in buddy-classloading and didn't make it optionally depended on log4j. I tried to leave my version of commons-logging (1.1) and copy the manifest from WTP, but it failed. It seems that the only thing needed to do was to downgrade commons-logging to 1.0.4.

But I don't think it closes this issue - commons-logging is used in my application, and tomcat plugin has commons-logging jar inside... I need to find some explaination for this... :) Also I'm not sure I want to downgrade commons-loggin g in my (pretty huge) production application, b/c it was painful experience to get it (version 1.1) working with other libraries and plugins I use :) :)

Any insights, please?...

Created an attachment (id=54833)
Output from commons-logging-1.1 with -Dorg.apache.commons.logging.diagnostics.dest=STDERR

This is the output of original testcase application (commons-logging-1.1) with  org.apache.commons.logging.diagnostics.dest property set. Help action is clicked, however nothing is written to the log on this action (all entries are generated before first logging invocation).

I've been staring at this problem for an hour and I still have no idea why it's happening. Your sample fails for me too, yet I see nothing wrong.

Somehow, the tomcat bundle is "reaching out" and using the commons logging classes from your bundle instead of using its own, even though it has no relationship to your bundle and doesn't depend on it. From what I know of the runtime the tomcat bundle shouldn't be able to see those classes at all.

Tom, I need your expertise on this one. Any idea why this would be happening?

My guess is that the commons-logging implementation is setting some singleton thing in the java.util.logging package and the first one wins.  Is that possible?  I'm not that familiar with the java.util.logging package or commons-logging.

(In reply to comment #9)
Thank you for answer. I guess commons-loggins creates singletons on first usage. But - if two classes are loaded by different classloaders and both creates singletons - shouldn't they be treated separately? (shouldn't see each other?)
And before all - shouldn't the help system be independent of any plugin you may possibly want to depend on?

When I traced through the code I saw that the org.eclipse.tomcat *was* loading the commons-logging classes from itself.  But then I got lost in the commons-logging code (which I did not have source to).  It looked like it was looking for a LogManager and finding one already registered by the other bundle.

Curtis, is there a place you keep the source for the binary libs in org.eclipse.tomcat so we can debug the code?
Thanks for looking into this Tom. We don't ship the source... I'll go download it and do some digging to find out where it's going wrong.
I think commons-logging-1.1 has a property to disable using thread context classloader. I never tried it though, maybe setting this will help, I'll check it.

Commons-loggins-1.1 has a property use_tccl that can be set in commons-loggins.properties. Setting it to false makes the testcase work (!) (yet I'm unclear why). I need to check if it improves something in my proper application. Also I'm not sure if that's a proper fix, b/c I'd rather think of a help system as  of a 'black-box' of some kind, so esoteric settings of 3rd party libraries should not impact any influence on it...
